sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Late Latin 'appretiationem' (a valuing, estimation), which is the noun form of 'appretiare' (to value, estimate, appraise). This Latin verb is from 'ad-' (to) + 'pretium' (price, value). The meaning evolved from simply 'setting a price' or 'valuing' to the more abstract senses of 'understanding value' (as in art appreciation) and 'feeling gratitude for value received'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. He showed his appreciation for their hard work by giving everyone a bonus.
2. My appreciation for classical music grew immensely after I started attending live concerts.
3. There's been a significant appreciation in the value of their property over the last decade.
4. Please accept this gift as a token of my sincere appreciation for your help.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
1. **In appreciation of:** As a way of showing thanks or recognition for. Example: We gave her flowers in appreciation of her dedication.
2. **Beyond appreciation:** So good or valuable that words cannot adequately express one's gratitude or enjoyment. Example: Her support was beyond appreciation.

title: appropriately
content:

Definitions:

Part of speech: Adverb

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Formed in English by adding the adverbial suffix '-ly' to the adjective 'appropriate'. 'Appropriate' comes from Late Latin 'appropriatus' (made one's own, set aside for oneself), the past participle of 'appropriare' (to make one's own, to take possession of). This Latin verb is from 'ad-' (to) + 'proprius' (one's own). The sense evolved from making something 'one's own' to making it 'suitable for a particular use or owner', hence 'fitting' or 'proper'.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. Please dress appropriately for the formal dinner, perhaps a suit or a dress.
2. The team responded appropriately to the sudden change in market conditions.
3. You need to react appropriately to constructive criticism, without getting defensive.
4. The software will automatically size the image appropriately for web display.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases

title: arbitrary

Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.

sections.title: Grammatical Information

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Originates from Latin 'arbitrarius' (of an arbitrator, depending on the will). This comes from 'arbiter' (a judge, umpire, supreme ruler, eyewitness). The meaning evolved from 'depending on the judgment of an arbiter' to 'depending on individual will or choice,' and then to its modern sense of being 'capricious' or 'random' due to a lack of rational basis.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. The teacher's grading seemed arbitrary, with no clear criteria for points awarded.
2. They made an arbitrary decision to close the park, without consulting local residents.
3. Her selection of colors for the painting appeared arbitrary, yet the final result was beautiful.
4. Many felt the new rules were arbitrary and unfairly targeted certain groups.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases

'Architecture' itself comes from Latin 'architectura' (the art of building), which is derived from Greek 'arkhitekton' (master builder). This Greek term combines 'arkhi-' (chief) + 'tekton' (builder, craftsman). The word has consistently referred to the principles and practice of building design.

sections.title: Grammatical Information

For Noun:

For Verb:

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: From Old French 'archives' (public records, archives), which came from Latin 'archivum' (a public office, records). This Latin term is from Greek 'arkheion' (public records, a public office), which is derived from 'arkhe' (government, public office, beginning). The core meaning has consistently related to official records and the places where they are kept, extending to digital storage in modern times.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. (Noun) Researchers spent months sifting through the family's old letters in the local archive.
2. (Noun) The university's archive contains rare manuscripts dating back centuries.
3. (Verb) We need to archive all completed projects by the end of the fiscal year.
4. (Verb) The historical society decided to archive all their photographs digitally to preserve them.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content: No widely common idioms or fixed phrases use 'archive' beyond its direct meaning. It is primarily used as a factual noun or verb.

sections.title: Grammatical Information
sections.content:
Part(s) of Speech: Noun, Verb

Noun:
Plural Form: arms

Verb:
Base Form: arm
Past Simple: armed
Past Participle: armed
Transitivity: Both transitive (Vt) and intransitive (Vi)
- Vt: 'to arm someone/something'
- Vi: 'to arm oneself' (reflexive)

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
The word 'arm' has two distinct etymological paths merging into one form:
1. **(Body part, chair part, branch)**: From Old English *earm*, tracing back to Proto-Germanic *armaz*, and further to Proto-Indo-European *armos* 'joint, shoulder', from the root *ar-* 'to fit together'.
2. **(Weapon, to equip)**: From Old French *arme* (weapon, noun) and *armer* (to arm, verb), both stemming from Latin *arma* (plural) 'weapons of war'. This Latin term also derives from the Proto-Indo-European root *ar-* 'to fit together', referring to equipment or fittings, but evolved a separate meaning for warfare. The convergence of form in English created a homograph.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. (N1) She carried the sleeping child gently in her arms.
2. (N2) He leaned back in the armchair, resting his head on its arm.
3. (N3) The soldiers were equipped with modern arms and ammunition.
4. (N4) The investigative arm of the government uncovered the corruption.
5. (V5) The rebels quickly armed themselves before the anticipated attack.
6. (V6) The politician was armed with compelling statistics for the debate.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases
sections.content:
•  With open arms: To welcome someone warmly and enthusiastically.
•  Twist someone's arm: To persuade or pressure someone to do something they are reluctant to do.
•  Arm in arm: Walking side by side, with arms linked, typically indicating intimacy, friendship, or solidarity.
•  At arm's length: Keeping someone or something at a distance, either literally or figuratively, often to avoid familiarity or involvement.
•  Give your right arm (for something): To be willing to sacrifice a great deal for something.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Derived from Old French *areier* 'to prepare, arrange, equip', later also 'to dress'. This word was formed from an intensive prefix *a-* (from Latin *ad-* 'to') and *rei* 'order, arrangement'. *Rei* comes from Frankish *raidjan* 'to prepare, arrange', which shares roots with Old High German *reiten* 'to prepare' and Old English *rædan* 'to advise, arrange'. The meaning shifted in Middle English to refer to an orderly arrangement.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. (N1) The store offered a stunning array of fresh fruits and vegetables.
2. (N2) The general reviewed the impressive array of troops before the parade.
3. (N3) In programming, an array is often used to store a list of related items efficiently.
4. (V4) The jewels were arrayed on velvet cushions for the exhibition.
5. (V4) The guests were elegantly arrayed around the banquet table.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content: Comes from Latin *articulatus* 'jointed', which is the past participle of *articulare* 'to divide into joints, to utter distinctly'. This, in turn, is derived from *articulus* 'a small joint', a diminutive of *artus* 'a joint, limb'. The meaning 'to speak distinctly' developed in English in the 16th century, stemming from the concept of clearly separating parts of speech, much like joints separate body parts.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. (Adj1) She is a very articulate speaker, always able to convey complex thoughts simply.
2. (Adj2) An articulated bus has a flexible joint connecting its sections, allowing it to turn tight corners.
3. (V3) It can be difficult to articulate exactly how you feel in moments of great emotion.
4. (V4) The actor worked hard to articulate every word perfectly for the stage performance.
5. (V5) The two bones articulate at the elbow joint, enabling a wide range of motion.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.content:
The word 'ash' has two distinct etymological origins that result in the same English form:
1. **(Residue)**: From Old English *æsce* 'ash', tracing back to Proto-Germanic *askōn*, and ultimately to Proto-Indo-European *as-/*aes- 'to burn, glow'.
2. **(Tree)**: From Old English *æsc* 'ash tree, spear (made of ash wood)', tracing back to Proto-Germanic *askaz*. This further derives from Proto-Indo-European *osk-* 'ash tree'. Despite their identical modern English form, these two meanings are rooted in different ancient words.

sections.title: Usage Examples
sections.content:
1. (D1) The campfire was reduced to a pile of gray ash by morning.
2. (D1) He flicked the cigarette ash into the ashtray, careful not to spill any.

4. (D2) Many ancient cultures revered the mighty ash tree for its strength and symbolism.

sections.title: Idioms and Phrases

•  Rise from the ashes: To recover completely from a disaster, defeat, or destruction and become stronger or more successful than before.
